title: Tour company cancels 'ghost tours' of serial killer site
text:
Save 
An Australian tourism company which ran serial killer “ghost tours” has cancelled its operations after facing criticism. 
Goulburn Ghost Tours confirmed on Tuesday that the company would no longer be running the Belanglo Forest ghost tours, where serial killer Ivan Milat buried his victims. 
The company had initially defended the tours, insisting they were run with “respect” and were not intended to upset anyone. 
However, they faced heavy criticism from the New South Wales government and victim support groups, the BBC reported. 
The company had been taking groups to Belanglo, which lies 75 miles south-west of Sydney. 
Milat is serving consecutive life sentences for murdering seven backpackers - two Britons, three Germans and two Australians - in the 1990s. 
A cached version of the Goulburn Ghost Tours’ website advertising the Extreme Terror Tour said people would visit Milat’s “old stomping ground”, calling it “this most terrifying of locations”. 
It added that it would use “paranormal techniques” to solve a murder. 
“Are you ready to turn grey overnight? Do you love to be frightened? Would you like to solve a crime? Then the GGT Extreme Terror Tour is for you!” it said. 
Goulburn Ghost Tours manager Louise Edwards told Channel Ten that the company had received a lot of hate mail but also many “poignant and thoughtful” emails about why the tours should be cancelled, which “made us see this in a different light”.
